question:
Starting from the garden, Mohit moves 15m to the west. He then turns to his right and moves 12m. Then, he turns 135 in the clockwise direction. In which direction he has to move to reach the starting point?


https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p24632/image014.png
solution:
Starting from the garden, Mohit moves 15m to the west. He then turns to his right and moves 12m.

Then, he turns 135 in the clockwise direction.

So, he has to move in the southeast direction to reach the starting point.


https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p24632/image015.jpg
https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p24632/image014.png

question:
Which of the following letter clusters will replace the question mark (?) in the series?

BY, DV, FS, HP, JM, ?, NG
solution:
BY
B + 2 = DY- 3 = V
D + 2 = FV - 3 = S
F + 2 = HS - 3 = P
H + 2 = JP - 3 = M
J + 2 = LM - 3 = J
L + 2 = NJ - 3 = G

So, option (d) is the correct answer.

question: The position of how many letters will remain unchanged if all the vowels followed by Consonants in the word 'TOURSER' are arranged in English alphabetical order?
solution:
TOURSER

After Re-arrangement:

EOURRST

Thus, the position of O, U and R remains unchanged.

So, option (c) is the correct answer.

question:
Which of the following numbers will replace the question mark (?) in the given series?

58, 70, ?, 88, 94, 98
solution:
Logic for the given series-

58 + 12 = 70

70 + 10 = 80

80 + 8 = 88

88 + 6 = 94

94 + 4 = 98

Hence, 80 will replace the question mark.

question:
Select the option that is related to the third letter cluster in the same way as the second letter cluster is related to the first letter cluster and the sixth letter cluster is related to the fifth letter cluster.

DNT: BFLPRV :: IMV : ? :: PGX : NREIVZ
solution:
A (1)B (2)C (3)D (4)E (5)F (6)G (7)H (8)I (9)J (10)K (11)L (12)M (13)
Z (26)Y (25)X (24)W (23)V (22)U (21)T (20)S (19)R (18)Q (17)P (16)O (15)N (14)
D (4)N (14)T (20)DNT
D - 2 = BD + 2 = FN - 2 = LN + 2 = PT - 2 = RT + 2 = VBFLPRV
I (9)M (13)V (22)IMV
I - 2 = GI + 2 = KM - 2 = KM + 2 = OV - 2 = TV + 2 = XGKKOTX
P (16)G (7)X (24)PGX
P - 2 = NP + 2 = RG - 2 = EG + 2 = IX - 2 = VX + 2 = ZNREIVZ

Thus, the answer is an option (a).

_P_ _ FB_LL_B_ _L_
solution:
Option (a) LPPBFBBLLFBLPLB

Here, no definite pattern can be established. So, option (a) is incorrect.

Option (b) FPBLFBPLLPBFLLL

Here, no definite pattern can be established. So, option (b) is incorrect.

Option (c) BPLLFBPLLFBPLLF

Here, the pattern 'BPLLF' is repeating.

Option (d) FPBPFBLLLBBBLLP

Here, no definite pattern can be established. So, option (d) is incorrect.

question: In a certain code language, "TEACH" is coded as "19-6-2-2-7" and "DANCE" is coded as "3-2-13-2-6". How will "IMAGE" be coded in that language?
solution:
In this code, the consonants are numbered by the immediately previous number and vowels are numbered by the immediately next number according to the alphabetical series.

Vowels are a, e, i, o, u and the rest are consonants.

ABCDEFGHIJKLM
12345678910111213
26252423222120191817161514
ZYXWVUTSRQPON

TEACH: 19-6-2-2-7

DANCE: 3-2-13-2-6

IMAGE: 10-12-2-6-6

So, option (c) is the correct answer.

question:
Three statements are given followed by two conclusions numbered I and II. Assuming the statements to be true, even if they seem to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the conclusions logically follow(s) from the statements.

Statements:

No P is Q

Mostly Q is R

Only a few R is S

Conclusions:

I: Some Q is not S

II: All R being P is a possibility
option_2: Neither conclusion I nor II follows
option_4: Both conclusions I and II follows
solution:
Venn diagram:

Conclusions:

I: Some Q is not S ---- Does not follow as we can't say it definitely.

II: All R being P is a possibility ----- this definitely does not follow because Mostly Q are R and No P is Q.

So, neither conclusion I nor II follows.


https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p25399/image003.png

question:
Three statements are given followed by three conclusions numbered I, II and III. Assuming the statements to be true, even if they seem to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the conclusions logically follow(s) from the statements.

Statements:

All Books are paper

No paper is Novel

All Notes are Novel

Conclusions:

I: No Book is Notes

II: No Paper is Notes

III: Some Notes may be Books
option_4: Both conclusion I and II follows
solution:
Venn diagram:

Conclusions:

I: No Book is Notes ----- True as no paper is novel ---- So Follow

II: No Paper is Notes ----- True as no paper is novel ---- So Follow

III: Some Notes may be Books ---- Can't say as it can be possible ---- So Does not follow

So, both conclusion I and II follows.

Thus, option (d) is the correct answer.

question: Eight persons are sitting in a linear row facing the south direction. Four persons sit between C and F. A sits third to the left of C. F sits at the end of the row. G sits immediate right of D. Neither D nor B sits adjacent to A. E sits second to the right of H. How many persons sit between H and G?
solution:
Four persons sit between C and F.

F sits at the end of the row.

A sits third to the left of C.

G sits immediate right of D.

Neither D nor B sits adjacent to A.

E sits second to the right of H.

Five persons sit between H and G.

of D.

question: 9 is related to 44 following a certain logic. Following the same logic, 18 is related to 89. To which of the following is 25 related to, following the same logic?
solution:
9 is related to 44 following a certain logic. Following the same logic, 18 is related to 89.

Here, the logic is:

9 * 5 - 1 = 45 - 1 = 44

18 * 5 - 1 = 90 - 1 = 89

Similarly,

25 * 5 - 1 = 125 - 1 = 124

question:
Four of the following five are somehow similar and therefore create a group. Which is not related to this group?

Fear, Surprise, Anger, Excitement, Commitment
solution: Fear, Surprise, Anger and Excitement are emotions but commitment is an action.

question: In a certain code language, CARTOONS is coded as BCNOORSU and PLATFORM is coded as BFLMOPRU. Then what will be the code for PROMISES in that code language?
solution:
Here, the letters of the words are arranged in alphabetical order. The letters which are at the ends of the newly formed words are replaced by the next letter in English alphabetical order.

CARTOONS -- ACNOORST -- BCNOORSU

PLATFORM -- AFLMOPRT -- BFLMOPRU

Similarly, PROMISES -- EIMOPRSS -- FIMOPRST

question:
Select the triad which follows the same pattern as that followed by the two triads given below. Both triads follow the same pattern.

NM - R - WD

VE - J - OL
solution:
Here, the pattern is:

M + 5 = R; R + 5 = W and the reverse pairs of M and W are N and D, respectively.

E + 5 = J; J + 5 = O and the reverse pairs of E and O are V and L, respectively.

Option (a) BY - C - IR

Y + 4 = C; C + 6 = I and the reverse pairs of Y and I are B and R, respectively. So, option (a) is incorrect.

Option (b) FU - X - AZ

U + 3 = X; X + 3 = A and the reverse pairs of U and A are F and Z, respectively. So, option (b) is incorrect.

Option (c) QJ - O - TS

J + 5 = O; O + 5 = T and the reverse pairs of J and T are Q and G, respectively. So, option (c) is incorrect.

Option (d) KP - U - ZA

P + 5 = U; U + 5 = Z and the reverse pairs of P and Z are K and A, respectively. So, option (d) is correct.

question:
By interchanging the given two numbers (not digits) which of the following equations will be correct?

36 and 48
solution:
By interchanging the given two numbers, 36 and 48 (not digits), the equations will be:

Option (a) 3 x 48 - 36 + 10

= 144 - 36 + 10

= 154 - 36

= 118

So, option (a) is incorrect.

Option (b) 36 - 5 x 48 ÷ 6

= 36 - 5 x 8

= 36 - 40

= -4

So, option (b) is incorrect.

Option (c) 36 ÷ 6 + 48 ÷ 2

= 6 + 24

= 30

So, option (c) is correct.

Option (d) 54 - 36 ÷ 3 + 48

= 54 - 12 + 48

= 102 - 12

= 90

So, option (d) is incorrect.

question:
Read the following statements and answer the question.

A@B means A is the father of B

A#B means A is the mother of B

A$B means A is the sister of B

A&B means A is the husband of B

If Satish & Mamta # Deepika $ Anmol & Jiya, then how is Satish related to Jiya?
solution:
Satish & Mamta: Satish is the husband of Mamta

Mamta # Deepika: Mamta is the mother of Deepika

Deepika $ Anmol: Deepika is the sister of Anmol

Anmol & Jiya: Anmol is the husband of Jiya

So, Satish is the father-in-law of Jiya.


https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p24899/image003.jpg

question: Pandit Shivkumar Sharma was a renowned _______ player.
solution:
Pandit Shivkumar Sharma was a legendary Indian classical musician and santoor virtuoso.

He is credited with shifting the instrument from a predominantly accompaniment and ensemble role in the Sufi music of Kashmir to a solo role in the Hindustani classical music tradition of North India, according to Britannica.

question: Which of the following is not a 'Rabi Crop'?
solution:
Paddy is not a Rabi crop, it is a Kharif crop. Kharif crops are grown with the onset of monsoon in different parts of the country and these are harvested in September-October. Important crops grown during this season are paddy, maize, jowar, bajra, tur (arhar), moong, urad, cotton, jute, groundnut and soybean

Rabi crops are sown in winter from October to December, and harvested in summer from April to June. Some of the important Rabi crops are wheat, barley, peas, gram and mustard. These crops are grown in large parts of India, states from the north and north-western parts such as Punjab, Haryana, Himachal Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir, Uttarakhand and Uttar Pradesh.

question: According to which of the following Articles of the Constitution of India shall a Money Bill NOT be introduced in the Council of States?
solution:
According to Article 109 of the Constitution of India, a Money Bill shall not be introduced in the Council of States.

This article outlines the special procedure for handling Money Bills in the Indian Parliament.

Further insights:

Article 354: Deals with the application of provisions relating to the distribution of revenues while a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation. It allows the President to modify the distribution of revenues between the Union and the States during a national emergency.

Article 298: Deals with the power of the Union to carry on trade or business. It allows the Union to carry on any trade or business and to do any act which could be done by a private individual.

Article 193: Penalty for sitting and voting before making oath or affirmation under Article 188, or when not qualified or when disqualified

question: According to the Industrial Policy Resolution 1956, industries in which of the following schedules were the sole responsibility of the state?
solution:
- Industrial Policy Resolution, 1956 -The industries were classified into three categories.

- Schedule A: Those industries which were to be the sole responsibility of the State. This list included 17 industries - arms and ammunition, atomic energy, iron and steel, heavy machinery required for mining, heavy electrical industries, coal, mineral oils, mining, iron ore and other important minerals (like copper, lead and zinc, etc.), aircraft, air transport, railways, ship-building, telephone, telegraph and wireless equipment, and generation and distribution of electricity.

- Schedule B: There were about a dozen industries on the list, where the State might establish new units or existing units might be progressively nationalised. In these industries, the private sector was guaranteed plenty of opportunities to develop and expand. It included the following industries: Other mining industries, aluminium and other non-ferrous metals not included in Schedule A, machine tools, ferro alloys, and steel tools, chemicals, antibiotics, and other essential drugs, synthetic rubber, pulp, road, and sea transport.

- Schedule C: Industries in this Schedule consisting of the rest of the industries, not included in Schedules A and B, would be in the private sector and would be subject to the social and economic policy of the government. The Industries (Development and Regulation) Act of 1951 and other relevant laws would apply to these industries.

question: In the year 1932, the famous Poona Pact was signed between __________, on behalf of Mahatma Gandhi, and Dr. Ambedkar.
solution:
Poona Pact was signed by Pt Madan Mohan Malviya and Dr. B. R. Ambedkar in 1932 at Yerawada Jail, Pune.

In 1932, the Britishers announced 'The Communal Award' by which separate electorates for the Dalits where only Dalits could vote. Mahatma Gandhi went on a hunger strike and objected to the provision of separate electorates for the Dalits.

question:
Consider the following statements about the Sattriya dance:

1) Sattriya dance is performed in Assam.

2) Khol (drum), Cymbals (Manjira) and Flute form the major accompanying instruments of this dance form.

Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
solution:
Statement 1 is correct: Vaishnava Saint Sankardeva is credited for introducing the modern form of Sattriya dance in 15th century AD in Assam. Vaishnava monasteries are called 'Sattras',where the dance was initially practiced, and from which the art form derives its name.

Statement 2 is correct: Khol (drum), Cymbals (Manjira) and Flute form the major accompanying instruments of this dance form. The songs are composed of Sankaradeva known as 'Borgeets'.

question: Common name for Calcium Phosphate is__________________.
solution:
Bone ash is a white material produced by the calcination of bones. It is primarily composed of calcium phosphate.

Chemical name of others:

Bleaching Powder - Calcium Hypochlorite

Blue Vitriol - Copper(II) Sulfate Pentahydrate

Caustic Soda - Sodium Hydroxide

question: Navtej Johar is associated with which of the following dance form?
solution:
Navtej Johar is associated with the Bharatanatyam dance form. He is a prominent Bharatanatyam dancer and choreographer. He won Sangeet Natak Akademi Award in 2014.

He was born in Jalandhar, Punjab, India on August 8, 1959 and is the first Sikh to pursue Bharatanatyam, which is often considered a feminine art form. Johar's work blends traditional and contemporary styles, and he has performed both Bharatanatyam and modern dance.

question: When can a President use his discretion in appointing the Prime Minister ?
option_1: When no political party enjoys a clear majority in the Lok Sabha.
option_2: Only when the Lok Sabha has been dissolved.
solution:
When no political party enjoys a clear majority in the Lok Sabha, the President uses his discretion in appointing the Prime Minister.

The President of India is the Head of State. The system of government of India is a cabinet form of government. The Indian President is, therefore, a constitutional head like the King or Queen of Britain - that is, all executive powers are constitutionally vested in him, although those are actually exercised and executed by the cabinet.

question:
Match the following.

Group A (Rivers)Group B (State of Origin)
I. Godavaria. Uttarakhand
II. Tapi b. Madhya Pradesh
III. Yamunac. Karnataka
IV. Cauveryd. Maharashtra
solution:
Correct code is 1-d, 2-b, 3-c, 4-a.

GodavariOriginates from Trimbakeshwar near Nasik in Maharashtra.
TapiOriginates in the Eastern Satpura Range of southern Madhya Pradesh
YamunaOriginates from the Yamunotri glacier at the Bandarpoonch peak in Uttarakhand
CauveryOriginates in the Brahmagiri hills in Kodagu, Karnataka

question: Who has written the book Sangeet Bal Prakash?
solution:
The book "Sangeet Bal Prakash" was written by Vishnu Digambar Paluskar.

He was a renowned Hindustani classical musician and a pioneer in the field of music education in India.

He sang the original version of the bhajan Raghupati Raghava Raja Ram.

Others:

Pandit Narayanrao Vyas: A renowned Hindustani classical vocalist of the Gwalior gharana. He was a disciple of Vishnu Digambar Paluskar and known for his powerful voice and expressive rendition of ragas.

Vishnu Narayan Bhatkhande: A musicologist and scholar who played a pivotal role in the revival and systematization of Hindustani classical music. He authored the seminal work "Sangeet Martand," a comprehensive treatise on Indian music theory.

Bhimsen Joshi: One of the most celebrated Hindustani classical vocalists of the 20th century. He was known for his powerful voice, unique style, and mastery of various ragas, particularly those of the Kirana gharana. He was awarded the Bharat Ratna, India's highest civilian honor, for his contributions to music.

question: Where is the 'Moidams - the Mound-Burial System of the Ahom Dynasty' located?
solution:
In an important cultural achievement for India "Moidams - the Mound-Burial System of the Ahom Dynasty" from Assam was officially inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List.

The announcement was made on 26th July, 2024, at the 46th session of the World Heritage Committee at New Delhi. This makes it the 43rd property from India to be included here.

This is the third World Heritage Property from Assam, following Kaziranga National Park and Manas Wildlife Sanctuary, both inscribed under the Natural category in 1985. The Moidams of Choraideo, which celebrate and preserve royal lineage through colossal architecture, are comparable to the pyramids of Egyptian pharaohs and royal graves in ancient China.

question: The idea of fundamental rights is taken from the constitution of which among the following countries?
solution: The Indian Constitution adopted the idea of fundamental rights from the Constitution of the USA (U.S.A's Bills of Rights). Along with fundamental rights, the Indian Constitution also borrowed the concepts of independence of judiciary, judicial review, impeachment of the president, removal of Supreme Court and high court judges and post of vice president.

question: Electric current is measured in
solution:
An electric current is a flow of electric charge.

The SI unit for measuring an electric current is the ampere, which is the flow of electric charge across a surface at the rate of one coulomb per second. Electric current is measured using a device called an ammeter.

In electric circuits this charge is often carried by moving electrons in a wire. It can also be carried by ions in an electrolyte, or by both ions and electrons such as in an ionised gas (plasma).

Others:

Candela (cd):

- The SI base unit of luminous intensity.

- Measures the brightness of a light source in a particular direction.

Farad (F):

- The SI unit of capacitance.

- Capacitance is the ability of a component (like a capacitor) to store an electrical charge.

Ohm (Ω):

- The SI unit of electrical resistance.

- Resistance is a measure of how much a material opposes the flow of electric current.

question: Who coined the term 'zeroth law of thermodynamics' in 1931, which asserts that two bodies in equilibrium with a third are in equilibrium with each other?
solution:
Ralph H. Fowler coined the term "zeroth law of thermodynamics" in 1931. This law is a fundamental principle in thermodynamics that establishes the concept of thermal equilibrium.

James Clerk Maxwell: While Maxwell did not explicitly state the zeroth law, his work on thermodynamics, particularly his kinetic theory of gases, laid the foundation for understanding temperature and thermal equilibrium. His ideas contributed significantly to the development of the concept.

Max Planck: Planck's work on black-body radiation and the development of quantum theory also played a role in the understanding of temperature and thermal equilibrium. His contributions helped to solidify the concept of temperature as a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles in a system.

Josiah Willard Gibbs: Gibbs' work on thermodynamics, particularly his development of the concept of chemical potential, was crucial in establishing the principles of thermal equilibrium. His contributions helped to formalize the mathematical framework for understanding these concepts.

question: Inflation is indicative of the decrease in the _________________of a unit of a country's currency.
solution:
Inflation is indicative of the decrease in the purchasing power of a unit of a country's currency.

For example, if a loaf of bread costs Rs.20 today and inflation causes the price to rise to Rs.30 next year, your Rs.20 will now buy less bread, indicating a decrease in its purchasing power.

question: The first fullerene molecule discovered was
solution: A fullerene is a molecule of carbon in the form of a hollow sphere, ellipsoid, tube, and many other shapes. Spherical fullerenes are also called Buckminsterfullerene and they resemble the balls used in football. The first fullerene molecule to be discovered, and the family's namesake, buckminsterfullerene (C60), was prepared in 1985 by Richard Smalley, Robert Curl, James Heath, Sean O'Brien, and Harold Kroto at Rice University.

question: In which ship the Royal Indian Navy Revolt originated?
solution: The RIN revolt started on 18 February 1946 in Bombay. The naval ratings on HMIS Talwar protested against the poor quality of food and racial discrimination by British officers. The protest spread rapidly to the Castle and Fort barracks on shore, and to 22 ships in Bombay harbour.

question: The Chola kingdom was known for its efficient administration. The smallest administrative unit was the ________
solution:
Nadu was the smallest administrative unit in the Chola kingdom.

Key Administrative Units:

For the administrative purpose, the Cholas divided their empire into nine provinces called mandalams headed by governors.

It was not uncommon for princes to be appointed as governors of mandalams.

The governors were in constant touch with the central government and sent regular replies to the king. Generally Mandalams were named after the original names or the titles of the Chola kings.

Mandalam was made up of several Valnadus which itself was the group of nadus.

The nadus is also known by another name referred to as kurram in Chola inscriptions as it informs that the number of kurrams constituted a Valnadu.

A village (Ur) in the Chola empire was a self-governing unit.

A number of such villages constituted a Kurram in different parts of the Chola country. Taniyur was a large village big enough to be a Kurram by itself.

question: With which of the following sport is Swapnil Kusale associated?
solution:
In a historic achievement, Swapnil Kusale has become the first Indian shooter to secure a medal in the 50m Rifle 3 Position (3P) event at the Paris Olympics.

Swapnil, a Target Olympic Podium Scheme (TOPS) athlete, showcased remarkable resilience and precision. He steadily climbed the ranks to finish 3rd with a total score of 451.4 points, Securing a Bronze medal for the nation.

In 2015, he won gold in 50m rifle prone 3 in the junior category in 2015 Asian Shooting Championships in Kuwait. He also won the 59th National Shooting Championship held in Tughlakabad ahead of Gagan Narang and Chain Singh in the 50m rifle.

question: What is the population density of India as per Census 2011?
solution:
· Population density is calculated as the number of persons per unit area. India is one of the most densely populated countries of the world.

· The population density of India as per the Census 2011 is 382 per sq-km.

· Literacy rate: 74.04%; Sex ratio: 940 females/ 1000 males; child sex ratio (0-6 years): 919.

question: In which year were the first modern Olympic Games held?
solution: The inaugural modern Olympic Games took place in Athens, Greece, in 1896. These Games were organized and revived by Pierre de Coubertin, a French educator and founder of the International Olympic Committee (IOC). The modern Olympics were inspired by the ancient Olympic Games held in ancient Greece from the 8th century BCE to the 4th century CE.

question: Dadabhai Naroji prepared the first estimation of national income in:
solution:
Dadabhai Naroji prepared the first estimation of national income in 1867-68.

• He estimated per capita income of Rs.20

• Central Statistical Organisation (CSO) has been entrusted with the task of calculating the national income post independence.

question: Which ocean is the saltiest?
solution: The Atlantic Ocean, also known as the Southern Ocean, is the saltiest ocean, mainly because it is colder and less diluted by freshwater inputs compared to other oceans. The Atlantic Ocean is the second-largest of the world's five oceans, with an area of about 85,133,000 km².

question: The movement of water through the soil, and its layers, by gravity and capillary forces is known as ______.
solution:
Percolation is the movement of water though the soil, and its layers, by gravity and capillary forces. The prime moving force of groundwater is gravity.

Guttation is the process by which plants release excess water in liquid form from the tips or edges of their leaves.

Leaching is the removal of soluble substances from the soil by the downward movement of water.

Transpiration is the process by which plants release water vapor into the atmosphere through their leaves.

question: Four shops named as A, B, C, and D offer successive discounts on an article such as shop A offers 50% and 10%, shop B offers 45% and 15%, shop C offers 30% and 30%, and shop D offers 40% and 20% respectively. Which offer is best for the customer?
solution:
In each shop, the sum of successive discounts is same so in these types of question, find the difference between the successive discounts offered by each shop. The difference of which shop is highest among the other shops will be the best for customer.

Difference in discounts in shop A = 50 - 10 = 40

Difference in discounts in shop B = 45 - 15 = 30

Difference in discounts in shop C = 30 - 30 = 0

Difference in discounts in shop D = 40 - 20 = 20

So, offer given by shop A, will be the best for customer.

question: Udit and Aman participated in a race where both started the race with speed in the ratio 4: 5 respectively. Udit covers 480 mts in 50 seconds then find after how much time Aman is 612 mts ahead of Udit?
solution:
Udit covers 480 m in 50 seconds

Therefore, speed of Udit = 480/50 = 9.6 m/s

Speed of Aman = (9.6*5)/4 = 48/4 = 12 m/s

Relative speed when both are running in same direction = 12 - 9.6 = 2.4 m/s

Time required by Aman to get 612 mts ahead of Udit = 612/relative speed

= 612/2.4

= 255 seconds

= 4.25 minutes = 4 minutes 15 seconds

question: The difference between the number of marbles in jar A and jar B is 50. The number of marbles in jar C is 10% more than that of in jar A and 20% more than that in jar B respectively. The number of marbles in jar C is:
solution:
Let number of marbles in jar C = X

Then number of marbles in jar A = X * 100/110 = 10X/11

And number of marbles in jar B = X * 100/120 = 5X/6

According to Question,

(10X/11) - (5X/6) = 50

5X/66 = 50

X = 10 * 66

X = 660

question: If two types of liquids worth Rs.302 per L and Rs.350 per L respectively, are mixed in the ratio of 9: 5, then what is the cost (in Rs.) (Nearest to the whole number) of the resulting mixture per L?
Rajni invests Rs. X for 4 months and Harini invests Rs. 1200 for 6 months. Find the value of 'X' if Rajni and Harini received amount of profit in the ratio 5 : 6.
solution:
According to question,

Ratio of Profit of Rajni to Profit of Harini

=> X * 4 : 1200 * 6 = 5 : 6

X = Rs. 1500

question: Find the sum of the average of the first 437 numbers and the average of the first 324 numbers?
solution:
"

As we know, sum of first n numbers = n(n + 1)/2

Average of first n numbers = n(n + 1)/2n = (n + 1)/2

Hence,

Average of the first 437 numbers = (437 + 1)/2 = 438/2 = 219

Average of the first 324 numbers = (324 + 1)/2 = 325/2 = 162.5

Required sum = 219 + 162.5 = 381.5

"
https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/stubeimg/SSCT-MML-005321.png

question: The area of the part between two concentric circles, whose circumferences are 176 cm and 220 cm, is
solution:
According to question,

Circumference of outer circle = 2 * 22/7 * r = 220 cm

r = 220/2 * 7/22 = 35 cm

Circumference of inner circle = 2 * 22/7 * R = 176 cm

r = 176/2 * 7/22 = 28 cm

Required area = (22/7) * (352 - 282)

= (22/7) * (35 + 28) * (35 - 28)

= 22 * 63

= 1386 sq. cm

question: In a quadrilateral PQRS, bisectors of ∠Q and ∠R meets at point O and ∠P - ∠S = 24˚. If ∠QOR = 107˚, then what is the measure of ∠P?
solution:
In the given quadrilateral PQRS:

∠Q/2 + ∠R/2 + ∠QOR = 180˚

∠Q + ∠R = 2 * (180˚ - 107˚) = 146˚

∠P + ∠Q + ∠R + ∠S = 360˚

146˚ + ∠P + ∠S = 360˚

∠P + ∠S = 214˚

Now, ∠P - ∠S = 24˚

∠S = 214˚ - ∠P = ∠P - 24˚

∠P = 119˚

question:
The given histogram represents the frequency distribution of people who visited hospital from morning 9:00 am to evening 6:00 pm:

What is the ratio of number of people who visited hospital in between 9:00 am and 12:00 pm to the number of people who visited hospital in between 3:00 pm and 6:00 pm?


https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p22821/image004.png
solution:
The number of people who visited hospital in between 9:00 am and 12:00 pm = 132 + 96 + 126 = 354

The number of people who visited hospital in between 3:00 pm and 6:00 pm = 108 + 136 + 144 = 388

So, required ratio = 354: 388 = 177: 194

question:
Directions: The following graph shows the percentage distribution of boys from class 6th to 10th.

Total number of boys from class 6th to 10th = 420

The difference between the total number of boys in class 7th and 8th and the total number of boys in class 9th and 10th is:


https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p18240/image005.png
solution:
Total percentage of number of boys in class 7th and 8th = 25 + 20 = 45%

Total percentage of number of boys in class 9th and 10th = 15 + 30 = 45%

Required difference = (45% - 45%) of 420 = 0

question: A sum of money is invested at r% rate of simple interest for 3 years. If he invested it at (r + 5)% rate of simple interest he would have fetched Rs. 342 more. Find the principal amount.
solution:
According to question,

5% rate continuous for 3 years will make difference of 15%

15% = 342

1% = 22.8

Sum of money = 100% = 100 * 22.8

=> Rs. 2280

question:
The following table shows the cost of 1 kg of mangoes and 1 kg of apples in five cities. Study the table and answer the question that follows.

CityCost of 1 kg of mangoes (in ₹)Cost of 1 kg of apples(in ₹)
J120200
K100180
L160140
M150280
N180300

Find the sum of cost of 3 kg of mangoes in city L and cost of 4 kg of apples in city K together.
solution:
Cost of 3 kg of mangoes in city L = 3*160 = ₹480

Cost of 4 kg of apples in city K = 4*180 = ₹720

Required sum = 480 + 720 = ₹1200

question: X and Y can complete a piece of work in 8 days and 24 days respectively. X works at Rs. 20/day and Y works at Rs. 50/day. X and Y together completed the work. What is the sum of amount received by X and Y?
solution:
Total work = LCM of 8 and 24 = 24 units

Efficiency of X = 24/8 = 3 units

Efficiency of Y = 24/24 = 1 units

Time taken to complete the work when X and Y both working together = 24/4 = 6 days

Required amount = 6 * 20 + 6 * 50 = 70 * 6 = Rs. 420

9999/271 gives 243 remainder as can be seen from above division.

question: A man earns a profit of 30% by selling a phone for a certain price. If he sells that phone at 3 times of selling price, then what will be the profit percentage?
solution:
Let the cost price of phone be Rs.100

Selling price at 30% profit = 100 * 130/100 = Rs.130

New selling price = Rs.130 * 3 = Rs.390

Profit% = (390 - 100) * 100/100 = 290%

question:
From among the words given in bold, select the incorrectly spelt word in the following sentence.

The comerrcial space industry is expanding, with private companies contributing to space exploration and satellite deployment.
solution:
Among the given options, the word 'comerrcial' is incorrectly spelt.

Commercial: Relating to or engaged in commerce, business, or trade.

Hence, option (c) is the correct answer.

Exploration: The systematic investigation of a subject or theme.

Deployment: The movement or positioning of resources for a specific purpose or task.

question:
Select the most appropriate meaning of the given idiom.

Below the belt.
solution:
The meaning of the idiom 'below the belt' is 'disregarding the rules; unfair'. Accordingly, the correct answer is given in option (a), 'Playing unfairly'.

Hence, the correct answer is option (a).

question:
Select the option that can be used as a one-word substitute for the given group of words.

A chemical liquid that destroys bacteria infecting non-living objects
solution:
Disinfectant: A chemical liquid that destroys microorganisms infecting non-living objects

Analgesic: (of a drug) acting to relieve pain

Herbicide: a substance that is toxic to plants, used to destroy unwanted vegetation

Anaesthesia: insensitivity to pain (especially as artificially induced before surgical operations)

Thus, the correct answer is option a).

question:
Select the most appropriate SYNONYM to replace the underlined word.

As a teacher, it's important to impart not only knowledge but also values to the students.
solution:
"Impart" means to transmit or pass on (information, knowledge, or something abstract) to someone. 'Convey' means to communicate or pass on information, knowledge, or values to someone. So, the two words can be used as synonyms of each other. Hence, (a) is the correct answer.

Withhold: To refuse to give or share something; to keep something back.

Retain: To keep or hold onto something; to continue to have possession or control of it.

Suppress: To forcibly put an end to something; to prevent the expression or development of something.

question: Select the INCORRECTLY spelt word.
solution:
Option (b) is the correct answer. The correct spelling is 'willpower'.

Judicious: having, showing, or done with good judgement or sense.

Willpower: control exerted to do something or restrain impulses.

Fasten: close or do up securely.

Sentiment: a view or opinion that is held or expressed.

question:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.

P. But now a chance acquaintance, talking of college life, showed him how meagre his learning was.

Q. He began to think and wonder about things that he had never considered before.

R. At last his new thirst for knowledge led him to ask his father for more schooling.

S. Well content with such a life, Nathaniel Greene reached the age of fourteen.
solution:
S begins the passage by introducing the main character - Nathaniel Greene. P follows by telling us how he learned that his learning was meagre. Q continues by telling us how he began to wonder and think about things he had never considered - this follows the line of thought described in P. R concludes the passage by telling us how this new thirst for knowledge led him to ask his father for more schooling. SPQR is the correct order.

Hence, option a) is correct.

question:
Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the given word.

Adversity
solution:
The word 'adversity' is a noun meaning a difficult or unpleasant situation. The most apt antonym of the given word is 'prosperity' (the state of being prosperous). Hence, option (b) is the correct answer.

Burst - An instance of breaking or splitting as a result of internal pressure or puncturing; an explosion.

Misfortune - Bad luck.

Attempt - Effort to achieve or complete a difficult task or action.

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice.

She needs to clean the floor right now.
option_1: The floor needs to be cleaned by her right now.
option_2: Cleaning of the floor needs to be done by her right now.
option_3: Right now cleaning of floor is needed by her.
option_4: She is needing right now to clean the floor.
solution:
Here, 'needs to' acts as a modal auxiliary verb.

In such sentences, we use: the modal auxiliary + be + 3rd form of the verb + by + agent.

Therefore, ‘needs to clean’ should be changed into ‘needs to be cleaned’. Option A is the correct choice.

question:
Select the most appropriate synonym of the boldened word.

Due to official parsimony only one machine was built.
solution:
'Parsimony' means extreme unwillingness to spend money or use resources. 'Frugality' means the quality of being economical with money or food; thriftiness. 'Generosity' means the quality of being kind and generous. 'Bounty' means a sum paid for killing or capturing a person or animal.

So, 'frugality' is the right synonym.

Hence, option (b) is correct.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement required'.

His boss ordered to let I and Anish to go to the hospital.
solution:
'Let' takes only an objective noun, and it does not take 'to-infinitive' after it. Both of these rules are not followed by the underlined part of the sentence. So, this part of the sentence is incorrect. Since 'I' is a subjective pronoun, option (c) is eliminated. Option (b) is eliminated as 'to-infinitive' grammatically incorrect in this sentence. 'Me' is an objective pronoun. Option (a) satisfies all the grammatical conditions mentioned above. Hence, option (a) is the correct answer.

NOTE:

Subjective Pronouns: The pronouns I, you, we, he, she, it, and they are known as subjective pronouns because they act as the subjects of verbs: We went to the party.

Objective Pronouns: The pronouns me, you, us, him, her, it, and them are called objective pronouns because they act as the objects of verbs and prepositions: Anjali drove us home.

Infinitive: The infinitive is the base form of a verb, often preceded by to.

Consider the sentences given below:

To err is human. [like a noun, the infinitive to err is the subject of the verb is]

My father likes to cook. [like a noun, the infinitive to cook is the object of the verb likes]

To vote in elections is our right. [the infinitive to vote, like a noun, is the subject of the verb is, but, like a verb, it also takes an object (elections)]

Radha went to the lake to fetch water. [the infinitive to fetch, like a noun, is the object of the verb went, but, like a verb, it also takes an object (water)]

The above sentences illustrate various ways in which infinitives are used. It can both act as a noun and a verb.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.

Have you give any thought to your future plans?
solution:
When using the auxiliary verb "have" in the present perfect tense, the past participle form of the main verb should be used. In this sentence, "give" is the base form of the verb, but it should be in its past participle form, which is "given." Hence, (a) is the correct answer.

The corrected sentence: Have you given any thought to your future plans?

Note:

An auxiliary verb, also known as a helping verb, is a verb used alongside the main verb in a sentence to form a verb phrase.

Participle: A word formed from a verb (e.g. going, gone, being, been) and used as an adjective (e.g. working woman, burnt toast) or a noun (e.g. good breeding). In English, participles are also used to make compound verb forms (e.g. is going, has been). Consider the sentences given below:

Dancing at the party, the women fell on the ground.

Encouraged by her parents, Rita went on to pursue her passion.

The highlighted word in the first sentence is of the form Verb + ing and is used as a present participle. It is used to denote an action that is going on or incomplete or imperfect.

The highlighted word in the second sentence is of the form verb + ed. It is used as a past participle. It denotes the completed action or state of the thing spoken of.

A past participle ends with the following: -ed, -d, -t, -en, or -n.

One should take great care and never get confused between a gerund and a present participle. They use the same forms but perform different functions: a gerund is a verbal noun, while a present participle is a verbal adjective.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement required'.

But if you want to save your cabbages from eating by caterpillars, you must use this solution.
solution:
The sentence should be in passive voice because the action is done on the subject 'cabbages'. Therefore, the underlined part of the sentence is grammatically incorrect as it is in active voice. Option (a) is eliminated as it is also in active voice. Option (c) is eliminated because it is grammatically incorrect. We cannot use a present participle verb after 'being'. Option (b) is in passive voice [being + v3] and it fits correctly in the given sentence. Hence, option (b) is the correct answer.

Note:

Active and Passive Voice: When the person doing the action is the subject, the sentence is said to be in active form/voice. When the subject is what the action is directed at, then the sentence is said to be in passive form/voice. For example: Active Voice: Rita and her friends performed a skit. Here 'Rita and her friends' (subject) perform the action. Passive Voice: A skit was performed by Rita and her friends. Here 'skit' is the subject (at which the action is directed).

question:
The following sentence has been split into three segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error. If you don't find any error, mark 'No error' as your answer.

He likes painting, dancing, / and to explore various/ forms of artistic expression.
solution:
One of the grammar rules is to make sure that sentence elements that are parallel in meaning are parallel in structure. So, 'to explore' needs to be replaced by 'exploring' in order to rectify the error. Hence, (d) is the correct answer.

The final corrected sentence: He likes painting, dancing, and exploring various forms of artistic expression.

question:
Select the grammatically correct sentence.

A. She is a honest person. She always tells the truth.

B. She is an honest person. She always tells the truth.

C. She is an honest person. She always tells an truth.

D. She is honest person. She always tells a truth.
solution:
The correct sentence is B. 'She is an honest person. She always tells the truth.'

The word 'honest' is an adjective that describes someone or something that is truthful, sincere, or fair. It starts with a vowel sound, even though it is spelled with an 'h'. For example, 'an honest answer', 'an honest mistake', etc.

In this case, the sentence 'She is an honest person. She always tells the truth.' is grammatically correct and complete. It means that she has the quality of honesty and she does not lie or deceive anyone.

Sentence A is incorrect because it uses 'a' before 'honest', which does not agree with the vowel sound it starts with. Sentence C is incorrect because it uses 'an' before 'truth', which starts with a consonant sound and does not agree with the article. Sentence D is incorrect because it does not use any article before 'honest' and uses 'a' before the uncountable noun 'truth' (here, 'the' should be used).

Hence, option (d) is the correct answer.

Note:

Definite and indefinite articles: In the English language, we have one definite article 'the'; it refers to or introduces, a particular, specific noun. 'An' and 'a' are indefinite articles; they refer to, or introduce, an unspecified noun.

Countable and uncountable nouns: 1. Countable nouns are the class of nouns that can be counted, for example, 'table' - one table, two tables, three tables, etc. 2. Uncountable nouns are nouns that cannot be counted or usually are not counted, for example, light, water, milk, information, furniture, etc. They do not generally have a plural form and can't be preceded by 'a' or 'an'. Many abstract nouns are typically uncountable. Some uncountable nouns can be used in the plural as well, depending on the meaning or context of the word.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank.

She has always been _____ to swim to build up the strength of her muscles.
solution:
The blank requires a verb in its participle form (after 'been'). So, options (a) [base verb] and (c) [s/es verb] are eliminated. The 'cycled' is eliminated as it does not provide a coherent meaning to the sentence. Among the remaining options, 'encouraged' (to fill with courage or strength of purpose) is the one that fits correctly in the blank as its use conveys her motivation. Hence,(d) is the right answer.

Note:

Participle: A word formed from a verb (e.g. going, gone, being, been) and used as an adjective (e.g. working woman, burnt toast) or a noun (e.g. good breeding). In English, participles are also used to make compound verb forms (e.g. is going, has been). Consider the sentences given below:

Dancing at the party, the women fell on the ground.

Encouraged by her parents, Rita went on to pursue her passion.

The highlighted word in the first sentence is of the form Verb + ing and is used as a present participle. It is used to denote an action that is going on or incomplete or imperfect.

The highlighted word in the second sentence is of the form verb + ed. It is used as a past participle. It denotes the completed action or state of the thing spoken of.

A past participle ends with the following: -ed, -d, -t, -en, or -n.

One should take great care and never get confused between a gerund and a present participle. They use the same forms but perform different functions: a gerund is a verbal noun, while a present participle is a verbal adjective.

question:
Select the most appropriate idiom that can substitute italicised words in the given sentence.

I hope I don't just die before I get to travel the world.
option_3: Hit the nail on the head
option_4: Cost an arm and a leg
solution:
The idiom "kick the bucket" is a colloquial and humorous way of saying to die or to pass away. In the context of the sentence, the speaker is expressing hope that they don't die before getting the chance to travel the world. Hence, (a) is the correct answer.

Break the ice: This expression means to initiate social interaction in a situation where there is tension or formality.

Hit the nail on the head: This idiom means to describe exactly what is causing a situation or problem.

Cost an arm and a leg: This expression is used to describe something very expensive.

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in active voice.

I have been removed from the post of Inspector.
option_1: The post of Inspector has removed me.
option_2: Somebody has removed me from the post of Inspector.
option_3: Removal of me has been done for the post of Inspector.
option_4: Somebody have removed me from the post of Inspector.
solution:
·The correct answer is(b) Somebody has removed me from the post of Inspector.

·The subject of the Passive Voice is changed into the object of the Active Voice. Also, the object of the Passive Voice is changed into the subject of the Active Voice.

·The removal of the helping verb is necessary while changing the voice of the sentence from Passive to Active.

·In the Passive voice, the sentence is in Present Perfect. Thus, in the Active voice, the sentence will be in Present Perfect.

·In Active voice, the introduction of "Somebody" is necessary for these types of sentences, where there is a vague pronoun in the Passive voice.

·For example:

o I have been robbed. (Passive)

o Somebody has robbed me. (Active)

·The options except (b) don't follow the correct grammatical format of the Active Voice.

Option (d) is incorrect because singular verbs are used with 'somebody' while 'have' is used with plural nouns.

·Therefore, the correct answer is:Somebody has removed me from the post of Inspector.

question:
Directions:

Directions [Set of 5 Questions]: In the following passage, some words have been deleted. Read the passage carefully and select the most appropriate option to fill in each blank.

In my book, I'll share what I've _______ (1) from more than a decade of studying climate change with experts and investing in the innovations we'll need to address it. I hope to ______ (2) the science in a clear and compelling way. I'll also propose a plan for what we need to do over the next decade and beyond to ______ (3) the tools that will help us eliminate greenhouse gas emissions while scaling up the powerful solutions we already have. And I'll suggest some concrete ______ (4) that individuals, governments, and companies can take to make it happen. I'm excited about the ______ (5) and eager to continue the conversation about how we can avoid a climate disaster.



Select the most appropriate option to fill blank (1).
solution:
After a cursory reading, we can figure that the author/speaker in the passage talks about a book of her/his in which s/he has shared the outcome of her/his study of climate change.

'Learning' (knowledge acquired through study, experience) is the outcome of studying something and looking at the sentence, we see that in the blank (1), we need a verb in its past participle form (so that 'have + past participle' forms a present perfect tense construct; to indicate that the process of 'learning' has already happened before the speaker/author started writing the book).

Combining these ideas, we see that 'learned' should be the best word to replace blank (1). ('Booked' is the past participle of 'book' which means 'reserve (a seat etc.); or make an official note of the personal details of (a person who has broken a law or rule)'; doesn't fit contextually here)

The answer is option (c).

question:
Directions:

Directions [Set of 5 Questions]: In the following passage, some words have been deleted. Read the passage carefully and select the most appropriate option to fill in each blank.

In my book, I'll share what I've _______ (1) from more than a decade of studying climate change with experts and investing in the innovations we'll need to address it. I hope to ______ (2) the science in a clear and compelling way. I'll also propose a plan for what we need to do over the next decade and beyond to ______ (3) the tools that will help us eliminate greenhouse gas emissions while scaling up the powerful solutions we already have. And I'll suggest some concrete ______ (4) that individuals, governments, and companies can take to make it happen. I'm excited about the ______ (5) and eager to continue the conversation about how we can avoid a climate disaster.



Select the most appropriate option to fill blank (2).
solution:
Writing a book to destroy (end the existence of something) or bully (seek to harm, or intimidate someone vulnerable) does not make sense. 'Alternative' (a noun meaning 'one of two or more available possibilities'; or an adjective meaning '(of one or more things) available as another possibility') is grammatically incorrect because we need a verb (in its base form) to make the 'to-infinitive' structure, to indicate the action. 'Explain' is the most appropriate alternative to replace the blank (2).

The answer is option (d).

question:
Directions:

Directions [Set of 5 Questions]: In the following passage, some words have been deleted. Read the passage carefully and select the most appropriate option to fill in each blank.

In my book, I'll share what I've _______ (1) from more than a decade of studying climate change with experts and investing in the innovations we'll need to address it. I hope to ______ (2) the science in a clear and compelling way. I'll also propose a plan for what we need to do over the next decade and beyond to ______ (3) the tools that will help us eliminate greenhouse gas emissions while scaling up the powerful solutions we already have. And I'll suggest some concrete ______ (4) that individuals, governments, and companies can take to make it happen. I'm excited about the ______ (5) and eager to continue the conversation about how we can avoid a climate disaster.



Select the most appropriate option to fill blank (3).
solution:
Here, we need a verb (in its base form) to make the 'to-infinitive' structure; thus, indicating the action. 'Constructed' (past participle); 'scientific' (adjective); and 'year' (noun) are grammatically unfit to replace the blank. 'Build' (strengthen) is the only good choice to replace the blank (3).

The answer is option (c).

question:
Directions:

Directions [Set of 5 Questions]: In the following passage, some words have been deleted. Read the passage carefully and select the most appropriate option to fill in each blank.

In my book, I'll share what I've _______ (1) from more than a decade of studying climate change with experts and investing in the innovations we'll need to address it. I hope to ______ (2) the science in a clear and compelling way. I'll also propose a plan for what we need to do over the next decade and beyond to ______ (3) the tools that will help us eliminate greenhouse gas emissions while scaling up the powerful solutions we already have. And I'll suggest some concrete ______ (4) that individuals, governments, and companies can take to make it happen. I'm excited about the ______ (5) and eager to continue the conversation about how we can avoid a climate disaster.



Select the most appropriate option to fill blank (4).
solution:
The use of 'some' in the sentence with blank (4) indicates that the required word should be a plural noun that can be qualified by the adjective 'concrete' (tangible; definite). Options (a) and (b) are singular nouns and hence are grammatically unfit here. Now the usage 'make it happen' requires one to make an effort and hence the word 'bricks' (rectangular blocks typically made of fired or sun-dried clay, used in building) doesn't make sense in the context. 'Steps' (measures; efforts) is the most appropriate choice here as 'concrete steps' (real/tangible measures) would result in 'making it happen'.

The answer is option (d).

question:
Directions:

Directions [Set of 5 Questions]: In the following passage, some words have been deleted. Read the passage carefully and select the most appropriate option to fill in each blank.

In my book, I'll share what I've _______ (1) from more than a decade of studying climate change with experts and investing in the innovations we'll need to address it. I hope to ______ (2) the science in a clear and compelling way. I'll also propose a plan for what we need to do over the next decade and beyond to ______ (3) the tools that will help us eliminate greenhouse gas emissions while scaling up the powerful solutions we already have. And I'll suggest some concrete ______ (4) that individuals, governments, and companies can take to make it happen. I'm excited about the ______ (5) and eager to continue the conversation about how we can avoid a climate disaster.



Select the most appropriate option to fill blank (5).
solution:
The required word should be a noun (because the determiner 'the' is used). 'Alarming' (worrying; disturbing) is an adjective and hence grammatically unfit. 'Festival' (a day or period of celebration) and 'house' are contextual misfits as the author does not touch upon these phenomena. 'Book' is the central theme of this passage and hence should be the most appropriate word to replace blank (5).

The answer is option (a).

question:
Select the option that can be used as a one-word substitute for the given group of words.

The practice or custom of having more than one wife or husband at the same time
solution:
'Polygamy' means 'the practice or custom of having more than one wife or husband at the same time'.

Hence, option (a) is the answer.

'Monogamy' means 'the practice of marrying or state of being married to one person at a time'.

'Endogamy' means 'the custom of marrying only within the limits of a local community, clan, or tribe'.

'Bigamy' means 'the act of entering into a marriage with one person while still legally married to another'.

question:
Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the word 'Intentional' from the given sentence.

Despite his careful planning, his success was merely accidental; he stumbled upon the solution by sheer luck rather than intention.
solution:
Intentional: done on purpose

Stumbled: to step awkwardly while walking or running

Accidental: happening by chance

So, 'accidental' is the right antonym.

Hence, option (c) is correct.

question:
Select the most appropriate synonym of the bracketed word in the following sentence to fill in the blank.

Over time, our ability to ______ (supervise) the changing climate has increased.
solution:
Supervise - observe and direct the work of (someone); observe and direct the execution of (a task or activity).

Monitor - observe and check the progress or quality of (something) over a period of time; keep under systematic review.

So, both words are similar in meaning. Hence, option (d) is the answer.

Neglect - fail to care for properly.

Leave - allow or cause to remain.

Overlook - to fail to notice or consider something or someone.
